awd_titl_txt: Analytic and numerical studies of long term  behavior in dynamical systems and differential equations
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to use computational and analytic methods to understand the long term dynamics of several problems that are specified by the Physics etc. The main tools used are analysis, topology and computation. One computes invariant manifolds by studying (numerically, analytically) the invariance equations satisfied by them and uses this as the skeleton. This requires to develop constructive versions of KAM theory, normal hyperbolicity as well as some novel objects such as the scattering map. This strategy can be applied also to renormalization maps (maps in the spaces of maps) and analyze some very chaotic systems.



The  unifying principle is  to find landmarks that organize the long term behavior in concrete systems. This is done using systematically numerical calculations and rigorous mathematics. The use of rigorous mathematics allows to work with confidence close to the breakdown of the objects considered, when the numerics becomes less clear.It is also well suited for applications when one needs to consider concrete mappings, for example in Astrodynamics or in chemical reactions. This involves projects of different levels and we plan to involve students in some of them. The students will get training both in numerics and in rigorous mathematics as well as be able to consider concrete problems.

por.por_cntn:
Simple rules, very often lead to complicated behaviors when
applied repeatedly. This simple observation has even entered
the popular culture with the name of "the butterfly effect".
Altering slightly the initial conditions can lead to enormous
changes over time.

When one encounters a system like this -- there are many in
practical applications -- the classical way (going back
to Poincare) to analyze it is
to find landmarks that behave in a predictable way. For example,
points that remain fixed or points that come back to themselves
after a certain time. One can also study the points which approach
some of the above in the future or in the past. When one has an
skeleton of orbits that are well understood, one can find ways to
understand the behavior.

In the proposal, we extended this approach using quite a number of
other landmarks (quasi-periodic orbits, normally hyperbolic invariant
manifolds). We tried to use at the same time methods based on rigorous
analysis and in numerical computation. These two methods reinforced
each other since the rigorous analysis gave confidence on
the computations. Very often geometric identities that lead togood proofs also lead to efficient algorithms. We also paid
attention to some problems coming from the natural sciences
and engineering. Many of the results were obtained with graduate
students or postdocs, who later found employment either in academia
or in industry.
